hero.subtitle: The world's first Cognitive Voice Fingerprint engine. MemoVoice identifies subtle linguistic drift years before clinical diagnosis — through natural conversation analysis powered by Claude AI.

problem.label: The Challenge
problem.title: The Silent
problem.p1: Alzheimer’s disease begins its assault on the brain up to 20 years before the first clinical symptom. By the time a patient receives a diagnosis, significant and irreversible neurodegeneration has already occurred.
problem.p2: Current diagnostic methods — cognitive tests, brain imaging, cerebrospinal fluid analysis — are expensive, invasive, and typically only deployed after noticeable symptoms emerge. The average diagnosis comes 2–3 years after symptom onset.
problem.p3: But research has revealed a crucial window: linguistic patterns begin to change years before other symptoms appear. These subtle shifts in how we speak — word choices, sentence structures, coherence patterns — are invisible to the human ear but detectable by AI.
problem.stage1Desc: Word-finding difficulties, reduced vocabulary diversity, simpler sentence structures begin to emerge in natural speech.
problem.stage2Desc: Semantic coherence declines, speech fluency changes, memory-dependent recall weakens across multiple domains.
problem.stage3Desc: Family and friends begin to notice changes. Traditional cognitive tests start to show decline. Neurodegeneration accelerates.
problem.stage4Desc: Formal diagnosis is made. Significant irreversible neurodegeneration already present. Treatment options are limited.

breakthrough.label: The Breakthrough
breakthrough.title: A World First in
breakthrough.subtitle: MemoVoice introduces the Cognitive Voice Fingerprint — a revolutionary approach to detecting Alzheimer’s through the subtle patterns hidden in everyday speech.
breakthrough.feature1Desc: A unique 25-dimension vector capturing the complete linguistic profile of each individual, creating a deeply personal cognitive baseline.
breakthrough.feature2Desc: Rather than comparing against population norms, MemoVoice measures each person against their own established baseline — detecting personal cognitive changes with precision.
breakthrough.feature3Desc: Through natural conversation — no blood draws, no brain scans, no clinical visits. Just regular phone or video calls analyzed in real-time by advanced AI.
breakthrough.feature4Desc: Illness, poor sleep, medication changes, and emotional distress are automatically factored in — reducing false positives and increasing clinical reliability.

howItWorks.label: How It Works
howItWorks.title: From Conversation to
howItWorks.subtitle: Four simple steps that could change everything for your family.
howItWorks.step1Desc: Natural phone or video calls with your loved one. No special equipment, no clinical setting — just everyday conversation.
howItWorks.step2Desc: Claude AI analyzes speech in real-time, extracting a 25-dimension cognitive feature vector across five linguistic domains.
howItWorks.step3Desc: Each session is compared against the individual’s personal cognitive baseline, detecting drift that population-level tests would miss.
howItWorks.step4Desc: A four-tier graduated alert system notifies clinicians and families of any significant cognitive drift, with detailed weekly narrative reports.

science.label: Scientific Foundation
science.title: Built on
science.subtitle: MemoVoice’s approach is grounded in peer-reviewed research from leading institutions in computational linguistics and neurodegenerative disease.
science.paper1Finding: Achieved 81.92% classification accuracy using linguistic features extracted from speech transcripts of the DementiaBank Pitt corpus, establishing that computational linguistic analysis can reliably detect AD.
science.paper2Finding: Demonstrated that connected speech analysis can track disease progression over time, with linguistic measures correlating directly with neuropathological severity at autopsy.
science.paper3Finding: Showed that automatic speech analysis can distinguish between healthy controls, MCI, and AD patients with high sensitivity and specificity — even at the pre-dementia stage.
science.paper4Finding: The ADReSS challenge established rigorous benchmarks for detecting Alzheimer’s from speech, demonstrating the viability of speech-only cognitive assessment across multiple research teams.
science.cascadeSubtitle: Based on Fraser 2016 taxonomy — tracking progressive linguistic deterioration stages

domains.label: Five Domains
domains.title: 25 Dimensions Across
domains.subtitle: Each conversation is analyzed across five scientifically validated linguistic domains, with five features extracted per domain.
domains.lexicalDesc: Vocabulary diversity, word frequency distribution, and type-token ratios. Among the earliest markers to show decline in Alzheimer’s progression.
domains.syntacticDesc: Sentence structure, clause embedding depth, and grammatical sophistication. Simplification patterns indicate disease progression.
domains.coherenceDesc: Topic consistency, propositional density, and logical flow between utterances. Critical for tracking semantic memory decline.
domains.fluencyDesc: Pause patterns, filler words, repetitions, and speech rate. Often the first domain to show pre-symptomatic changes detectable by AI.
domains.memoryDesc: Narrative completeness, temporal ordering, and detail retention. Directly reflects episodic and working memory function.
domains.compositeDesc: All 25 features combine into a single composite z-score measuring overall cognitive drift from the individual’s established baseline.

technology.label: The Technology
technology.title: Powered by
technology.p1: MemoVoice leverages Claude Opus 4.6 by Anthropic — one of the most advanced language models ever built — for both real-time feature extraction and deep clinical analysis.
technology.p2: Using Claude’s extended thinking capability, the system performs thorough clinical reasoning for weekly reports, considering the full context of a patient’s linguistic trajectory, confounding factors, and domain-specific patterns.
technology.p3: The result is a level of linguistic analysis that approaches — and in some dimensions surpasses — what human clinical linguists can achieve, delivered continuously and at scale.

families.label: For Families
families.title: For the People Who
families.subtitle: We built MemoVoice for families who want to protect their loved ones. Because the best time to act is before you notice something is wrong.
families.benefit1Desc: Continuous monitoring means you’ll know about cognitive changes as early as possible — not months or years after they begin.
families.benefit2Desc: Clear, jargon-free reports written for families. Understand your loved one’s cognitive health without a medical degree.
families.benefit3Desc: No clinical tests, no uncomfortable procedures. Just regular conversations — preserving your loved one’s dignity and comfort.
families.benefit4Desc: Early detection gives families critical time for care planning, treatment exploration, legal preparations, and meaningful time together.
families.quote: “If we had known earlier, we would have had more time. More conversations. More moments. That’s what early detection gives you — time.”

modes.label: Two Modes
modes.title: Prevention &
modes.subtitle: MemoVoice adapts to where your loved one is on their journey — whether you’re watching for early signs or supporting someone already diagnosed.
modes.preventionTitle: Families Share Memories, AI Leads the Conversation
modes.preventionDesc: You provide the memories — childhood stories, favorite holidays, career milestones, family traditions. MemoVoice’s AI weaves them into warm, natural phone conversations with your loved one.
modes.preventionStep1: Families upload memories: stories, names, places, life events
modes.preventionStep2: AI crafts personalized conversation topics from those memories
modes.preventionStep3: Regular phone calls feel natural — your loved one enjoys reminiscing
modes.preventionStep4: While talking, the CVF Engine silently analyzes 25 cognitive dimensions
modes.preventionStep5: Families receive weekly cognitive drift reports
modes.preventionKey: Your loved one never feels tested. They simply enjoy a conversation about their own life — while MemoVoice watches for the earliest signs of cognitive change.
modes.treatmentTitle: Memory Activation Therapy for Diagnosed Patients
modes.treatmentDesc: For people already diagnosed with Alzheimer’s or MCI, MemoVoice becomes a therapeutic tool. AI-guided phone calls use personal memories to actively stimulate cognitive pathways and slow decline.
modes.treatmentStep1: Structured reminiscence sessions built around the patient’s life story
modes.treatmentStep2: AI progressively guides recall from strong memories to weaker ones
modes.treatmentStep3: Repeated memory activation strengthens neural connections
modes.treatmentStep4: Sessions adapt in real-time to the patient’s cognitive state
modes.treatmentStep5: Clinicians receive detailed session reports tracking response patterns
modes.treatmentKey: Research shows that regular reminiscence therapy can improve mood, reduce agitation, and help maintain cognitive function. MemoVoice delivers this at scale — personalized to each patient’s unique life history.
modes.sciencePoint1: Reminiscence therapy is recognized by the Cochrane Collaboration as beneficial for mood and cognition in dementia patients
modes.sciencePoint2: Autobiographical memory stimulation activates the medial temporal lobe and prefrontal cortex — regions affected earliest by Alzheimer’s
modes.sciencePoint3: Regular cognitive engagement through meaningful conversation contributes to cognitive reserve and may delay functional decline

cta.subtitle: MemoVoice is currently in clinical development. Join our early access program to be among the first to experience the future of cognitive monitoring.

footer.brandDesc: Cognitive Voice Fingerprint Engine for early Alzheimer’s detection through linguistic analysis.
footer.bottomLine: MemoVoice CVF Engine v0.1.0 — Built at the Cerebral Valley x Anthropic Hackathon, February 2026

scientific.heroSubtitle: A deep dive into the Cognitive Voice Fingerprint engine, the 25-dimension analysis framework, and the clinical research that makes early Alzheimer's detection through voice possible.
scientific.engineDesc: The CVF Engine is the core of MemoVoice — a real-time linguistic analysis system that converts natural speech into a 25-dimension cognitive feature vector. Each conversation is processed through a multi-stage pipeline that extracts, normalizes, and compares linguistic features against the individual's personal baseline.
scientific.pipe1Desc: Voice input is captured via standard phone or video calls. The audio stream is segmented and prepared for transcription with noise filtering and speaker diarization.
scientific.pipe2Desc: Speech-to-text conversion produces a clean transcript. Text is normalized for filler removal, false starts, and cross-talk elimination while preserving diagnostically relevant disfluencies.
scientific.pipe3Desc: Claude Opus 4.6 with extended thinking analyzes the transcript across all 25 cognitive dimensions. Each feature is scored on a standardized scale using clinically-grounded rubrics.
scientific.pipe4Desc: Current session scores are compared against the individual's rolling baseline using z-score normalization. Statistically significant deviations trigger graduated alerts.
scientific.pipe5Desc: Weekly narrative reports synthesize multi-session trends, highlight concerning patterns, factor in confounders, and provide actionable clinical recommendations.
scientific.dimensionsDesc: Each conversation produces a 25-element vector spanning five linguistic domains. These dimensions were selected based on peer-reviewed research identifying the most sensitive markers of cognitive decline.
scientific.lexical1Desc: Measures vocabulary diversity — the ratio of unique words to total words. Declining TTR is among the earliest detectable markers of Alzheimer's.
scientific.lexical2Desc: A length-independent measure of lexical richness that remains stable across different text lengths, providing reliable cross-session comparisons.
scientific.lexical3Desc: Captures the proportion of words used only once (hapax legomena). Higher values indicate richer vocabulary; decline signals word-finding difficulties.
scientific.lexical4Desc: Tracks the distribution of common vs. rare words. Alzheimer's patients increasingly rely on high-frequency, generic terms as access to specific vocabulary degrades.
scientific.lexical5Desc: Monitors usage patterns across semantic categories (animals, tools, foods). Category-specific decline can indicate targeted semantic memory degradation.
scientific.syntactic1Desc: Average number of words per clause. Progressive shortening indicates simplification of grammatical structures.
scientific.syntactic2Desc: Measures nested clause complexity. Reduced embedding depth reflects declining ability to construct and maintain complex grammatical relationships.
scientific.syntactic3Desc: Proportion of dependent to independent clauses. Decreasing ratios suggest loss of syntactic sophistication.
scientific.syntactic4Desc: The maximum depth of syntactic parse trees. Shallower trees correlate with syntactic simplification in neurodegenerative conditions.
scientific.syntactic5Desc: Frequency of grammatical errors relative to utterance count. Increasing errors beyond personal baseline indicate declining syntactic competence.
scientific.coherence1Desc: Semantic similarity between adjacent utterances. Declining local coherence indicates difficulty maintaining topic continuity.
scientific.coherence2Desc: How well the overall narrative connects to the central topic. Global coherence breakdown is a hallmark of advancing Alzheimer's.
scientific.coherence3Desc: The number of ideas expressed per utterance. Reduced density reflects declining ability to pack meaning into speech.
scientific.coherence4Desc: Ability to stay on topic without tangential drift. Increasing topic shifts suggest executive function decline.
scientific.coherence5Desc: Proper use of pronouns and references. Ambiguous referencing (e.g., excessive use of 'thing' or 'that') indicates semantic access difficulties.
scientific.fluency1Desc: Number of pauses per minute of speech. Increasing pause frequency beyond personal baseline often precedes other symptoms.
scientific.fluency2Desc: Usage of 'um', 'uh', 'like', and other fillers. Changes in filler patterns reflect real-time word retrieval difficulties.
scientific.fluency3Desc: Words per minute, adjusted for pause time. Declining speech rate indicates increased cognitive processing demands.
scientific.fluency4Desc: Frequency of word and phrase repetitions. Increasing repetitions suggest working memory limitations.
scientific.fluency5Desc: Frequency of mid-sentence corrections and restarts. Changes in self-correction patterns reveal meta-cognitive awareness shifts.
scientific.memory1Desc: Proportion of expected story elements recalled. Declining completeness indicates episodic memory degradation.
scientific.memory2Desc: Ability to recount events in correct chronological order. Temporal confusion is an early marker of hippocampal dysfunction.
scientific.memory3Desc: Level of specific detail provided in narratives. Shift from specific to generic details signals memory access difficulties.
scientific.memory4Desc: Ability to provide additional detail when prompted. Declining responsiveness to cues indicates deeper memory retrieval failure.
scientific.memory5Desc: Consistency of recalled details across sessions. Increasing inconsistencies reveal progressing memory consolidation problems.
scientific.claudeDesc: MemoVoice leverages Claude Opus 4.6's extended thinking capability — allocating up to 10,000 tokens of internal reasoning before producing each analysis. This allows the model to consider the full complexity of linguistic patterns, personal history, and confounding factors before generating clinically relevant insights.
scientific.claudeFeature1: Multi-session trajectory analysis with trend detection
scientific.claudeFeature2: Confounder identification: illness, medication, mood, fatigue
scientific.claudeFeature3: Domain-specific pattern recognition across all 25 dimensions
scientific.claudeFeature5: Natural language clinical narratives for weekly reports
scientific.validationDesc: The CVF Engine's approach is grounded in decades of peer-reviewed research in computational linguistics and neurodegenerative disease detection.
scientific.study1: Fraser et al. (2016) — Achieved 81.92% accuracy detecting Alzheimer's from speech transcripts using computational linguistic features.
scientific.study2: Ahmed et al. (2013) — Demonstrated longitudinal connected speech analysis can track AD progression, correlating with neuropathological severity.
scientific.study3: König et al. (2015) — Showed automatic speech analysis distinguishes healthy controls from MCI and AD with high sensitivity at pre-dementia stages.
scientific.study4: Luz et al. (2020) — The ADReSS Challenge established rigorous benchmarks for Alzheimer's detection from speech across multiple research teams.
scientific.study5: de la Fuente Garcia et al. (2020) — Comprehensive review establishing linguistic markers as viable biomarkers for neurodegenerative conditions.

familyPage.heroSubtitle: MemoVoice gives families something priceless: the ability to detect cognitive changes in loved ones years before traditional methods — through simple, natural conversations.
familyPage.storyP1: It often starts with something small. A repeated question. A forgotten name. A pause where there never used to be one. And by the time the family notices, the disease has often been progressing silently for years.
familyPage.storyP2: Alzheimer's affects more than the person diagnosed — it reshapes entire families. The uncertainty, the delayed diagnosis, the feeling of lost time. MemoVoice was built to give families back what matters most: time.
familyPage.storyP3: With MemoVoice, you don't have to wait for something to feel wrong. Continuous monitoring means cognitive changes are detected at their earliest, most subtle stages — when intervention can make the biggest difference.
familyPage.dignityDesc: Your loved one never feels tested, examined, or reduced to a patient. MemoVoice works through warm, natural conversations about their own life — their memories, their stories, their experiences.
familyPage.dignity1Desc: Monitoring happens through regular phone calls from the comfort of home. No appointments, no waiting rooms, no intimidating medical equipment.
familyPage.dignity2Desc: AI-guided calls are designed to feel like catching up with an old friend. Topics are drawn from your loved one's own memories and life experiences.
familyPage.dignity3Desc: All conversations are processed with strict privacy protections. No data is sold, shared, or used for anything other than your loved one's cognitive monitoring.
familyPage.dignity4Desc: Weekly reports are written in clear, jargon-free language. You don't need a medical degree to understand your loved one's cognitive health.
familyPage.peace1Desc: Detect subtle cognitive changes years before they become noticeable. Early awareness means more options and better outcomes.
familyPage.peace2Desc: Early detection gives families critical time for care planning, financial preparation, legal arrangements, and treatment exploration.
familyPage.peace3Desc: Regular AI-guided conversations keep your loved one engaged and socially connected — proven to support cognitive health.
familyPage.peace4Desc: Data-driven insights replace uncertainty. Know when it's time to talk to a doctor, backed by objective cognitive monitoring data.
familyPage.quoteText: If we had known earlier, we would have had more time. More conversations. More moments where they were fully themselves. That's what early detection gives you — time.
familyPage.ctaTitle: Give Your Family the Gift of
familyPage.ctaDesc: Join our early access program and be among the first families to experience proactive cognitive monitoring.

opensource.heroSubtitle: MemoVoice's core CVF Engine is fully open source under the MIT license. We believe that technology for detecting cognitive decline should be accessible to everyone.
opensource.repoDesc: The complete source code is available on GitHub. Fork it, modify it, deploy it locally, or build your own cognitive analysis tools on top of it.
opensource.core1Desc: The complete 25-dimension cognitive feature extraction pipeline. Analyze speech transcripts and generate cognitive vectors using any compatible LLM.
opensource.core2Desc: Individual baseline computation and drift detection algorithms. Statistical comparison engine with configurable sensitivity thresholds.
opensource.core3Desc: Four-tier graduated alert system from routine monitoring through urgent clinical notification. Fully customizable thresholds and routing.
opensource.core4Desc: Weekly narrative report generation using AI. Produces clear, clinically relevant summaries of cognitive trends and patterns.
opensource.customDesc: The open source engine is designed to be modular and extensible. Swap out components, add your own analysis dimensions, or integrate with your existing infrastructure.
opensource.custom1Desc: Switch between voice providers — Twilio, Vonage, or any SIP-compatible service. The engine is voice-API agnostic.
opensource.custom2Desc: While optimized for Claude, the engine supports any OpenAI-compatible API. Use GPT-4, Llama, Mistral, or your own fine-tuned models.
opensource.custom3Desc: Run entirely on your own infrastructure. No external API calls required if you use a local LLM. Full data sovereignty guaranteed.
opensource.custom4Desc: Add or modify cognitive dimensions beyond the default 25. Define custom scoring rubrics tailored to specific conditions or research needs.
opensource.saasDesc: Don't want to self-host? MemoVoice also offers a fully managed SaaS platform with all the features of the open source engine, plus dedicated infrastructure, automatic updates, and clinical support.
opensource.saasFeature4: Dedicated onboarding and clinical support team

demo.heroSubtitle: Request a personalized demonstration and see how the Cognitive Voice Fingerprint engine detects subtle linguistic patterns in real-time.
demo.formDesc: Fill out the form below and our team will contact you within 24 hours to schedule a personalized demo.
demo.fieldOrgPlaceholder: Hospital, research lab, or company name
demo.fieldMessagePlaceholder: Tell us about your use case...
demo.submitNote: We'll respond within 24 hours. No spam, ever.
demo.expect1Desc: Watch the CVF Engine process a real conversation transcript in real-time, extracting all 25 cognitive dimensions and generating a cognitive vector.
demo.expect2Desc: Explore the monitoring dashboard — see how baseline comparisons work, how drift is detected, and how alerts are generated.
demo.expect3Desc: Review sample weekly narrative reports showing how cognitive trends are communicated to families and clinicians in clear, actionable language.
demo.expect4Desc: Ask our team anything about the science, the technology, deployment options, or how MemoVoice can fit your specific needs.
demo.preview2: Individual baseline tracking with drift detection

privacy.heroSubtitle: MemoVoice is built with privacy as a core architectural principle. We believe cognitive health monitoring should never come at the cost of personal privacy.
privacy.policyDesc: MemoVoice does not collect, store, or sell personal data. All cognitive analysis happens in real-time, and no conversation recordings or transcripts are retained beyond the immediate processing window.
privacy.policy1Desc: Audio recordings and transcripts are processed in real-time and immediately discarded. Only computed cognitive feature vectors are retained for baseline comparison.
privacy.policy2Desc: Your data is never shared with, sold to, or accessed by third parties. Period. No advertising, no data brokers, no exceptions.
privacy.policy3Desc: We don't track user behavior, browsing patterns, or usage analytics beyond what's strictly necessary for the service to function.
privacy.policy4Desc: All stored cognitive vectors can be exported or permanently deleted at any time by the account holder. Full data portability guaranteed.
privacy.hipaaDesc: MemoVoice is designed to meet HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) requirements for protected health information.
privacy.hipaa1Desc: All data in transit is protected with TLS 1.3 encryption. Stored cognitive vectors are encrypted at rest using AES-256.
privacy.hipaa2Desc: Role-based access control ensures only authorized users can view cognitive data. All access is logged and auditable.
privacy.hipaa3Desc: Complete audit trail of all data access, modifications, and deletions. Logs are tamper-proof and retained per HIPAA requirements.
privacy.hipaa4Desc: BAAs are available for all healthcare partners. Cloud infrastructure providers are HIPAA-certified and covered under their own BAAs.
privacy.encryptionDesc: Multiple layers of encryption protect data at every stage of processing.
privacy.encrypt1: TLS 1.3 for all data in transit
privacy.encrypt2: AES-256 encryption for data at rest
privacy.encrypt5: Hardware security modules (HSM) for key storage

legal.heroSubtitle: MemoVoice is committed to transparency in how we build, license, and envision the future of accessible cognitive health technology.
legal.mitDesc: The MemoVoice CVF Engine is released under the MIT License — one of the most permissive open source licenses available. You are free to use, modify, distribute, and build upon this software for any purpose.
legal.mitCondition: The only condition is that the original MIT license and copyright notice must be included in any copy or substantial portion of the software.
legal.hackathonDesc: MemoVoice was created at the Cerebral Valley x Anthropic Hackathon in February 2026. This event brought together developers, researchers, and AI enthusiasts to build meaningful applications using Anthropic's Claude AI.
legal.hackathonCredit1: Built using Claude Opus 4.6 by Anthropic
legal.hackathonCredit2: Developed during the February 2026 hackathon event
legal.hackathonCredit3: Cerebral Valley community for the platform and inspiration
legal.hackathonCredit4: All open source contributors and research community
legal.ngoDesc: We envision MemoVoice evolving beyond a hackathon project into a nonprofit organization dedicated to making cognitive health monitoring accessible worldwide.
legal.ngo1Desc: Cognitive decline affects families everywhere. As an NGO, MemoVoice could provide free or subsidized monitoring to underserved communities worldwide.
legal.ngo2Desc: Nonprofit status enables deeper collaboration with academic institutions, hospitals, and research organizations without commercial conflicts of interest.
legal.ngo3Desc: An NGO structure ensures that decisions about cognitive health AI are guided by ethics and patient welfare — not shareholder returns.
legal.ngo4Desc: The open source foundation means the technology belongs to everyone. An NGO would formalize this commitment to community ownership and transparent governance.
legal.disclaimerText: MemoVoice is currently a research and demonstration project. It is not a medical device and is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. The Cognitive Voice Fingerprint analysis is for research and informational purposes only. Always consult qualified healthcare professionals for medical advice and diagnosis.
